G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, which grants the Housing Court jurisdiction over all civil actions arising under or involving the rights or obligations of residential landlords and tenants.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease and tenancy in Massachusetts carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits landlords from permitting interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease and tenancy in Massachusetts carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits landlords from permitting interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and states that every tenancy is deemed to include an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment. It further explains that “quiet enjoyment” means freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy, and the landlord is liable where its acts or omissions that should have been foreseen as interfering with that enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that, under G.L. c. 186, § 14, residential leases carry an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that prohibits landlords from permitting interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

*Hemming v. Lovering*, 448 Mass. 485 (20.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition free from water infiltration constitutes a breach of this covenant.
*Hemming v. Lovering*, 448 Mass. 485 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is from a criminal homicide/DNA evidence case (Commonwealth v. Bly), not Hemming v. Lovering, and it concerns murder, DNA testing, suppression issues, eyewitness identification, and related criminal procedure. It does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, water infiltration, or any covenant to maintain premises. Therefore, this opinion cannot support the stated proposition about breach of a habitability covenant due to water infiltration.
*Hemming v. Lovering*, 448 Mass. 485 (20.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt available in the provided text, as it does not discuss landlord-tenant habitability, water infiltration, or covenants to maintain premises. The entire opinion concerns a murder prosecution and evidentiary issues.]

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition free from water infiltration constitutes a breach of this covenant.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case deals with breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction caused by excessive noise from a lounge operated on nearby premises, not by failure to maintain the premises free from water infiltration or general habitability/repair issues. While the court uses the phrase “not reasonably habitable,” it does so in the context of noise and control of third-party activity, not water intrusion or a duty to maintain the physical condition of the premises. Thus it does not specifically support the proposition about water infiltration breaching a habitability covenant.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A landlord’s inaction or neglect that allows substantial interference with a tenant’s use of the premises can amount to a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, even absent an intent to deprive the tenant of enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but only to apply it to the facts and conclude there was no interference. It does not articulate or endorse a rule that a landlord’s inaction or neglect, absent intent, can itself amount to a violation; instead it simply notes that generally the landlord must have notice and act at least negligently, and then finds no serious interference here. Thus, the case neither establishes nor applies the specific principle that negligent inaction amounting to substantial interference suffices for a § 14 violation without intent to deprive enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely repair a chronic water intrusion, despite notice, violated her duties under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.), which together require landlords to maintain rental units in a safe and sanitary condition.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely repair a chronic water intrusion, despite notice, violated her duties under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.), which together require landlords to maintain rental units in a safe and sanitary condition.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely repair a chronic water intrusion, despite notice, violated her duties under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.), which together require landlords to maintain rental units in a safe and sanitary condition.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly ties the landlord’s obligations to the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 111, § 127A as the source of a duty to maintain habitable premises, and it holds that a failure to provide adequate heat and hot water (code violations) constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability with rent abatement starting upon notice. However, the decision does not hold, or analyze, that the landlord’s conduct in this case constituted an independent statutory violation of G.L. c. 111, § 127A or of the Code as an actionable claim; rather, the Code is used to define the warranty’s content and to support rent abatement, not to find a separate statutory breach. Thus it does not directly support the proposition that the defendant’s failure to repair “violated her duties under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the State Sanitary Code” as an independent violation, though it is persuasive background authority for using those sources to define the landlord’s duty to keep the unit safe and sanitary.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code, adopted pursuant to authority granted in G. L. c. 111, § 5 (since amended, see G. L. c. 111, § 127A, for the current version), imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition… In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes…. The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201).”

*Winchester v. Chan*, 89 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions constitute an unreasonable and substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Winchester v. Chan*, 89 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Santos v. U.S Bank National Association
*Winchester v. Chan*, 89 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is about foreclosure, res judicata, and alleged negligence in processing HAMP loan modifications; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, a lease, or common-law nuisance claims regarding interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises. Nowhere does the opinion discuss whether a defendant’s acts or omissions constitute an unreasonable and substantial interference with use and enjoyment of leased property. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
*Winchester v. Chan*, 89 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In general, ‘[t]he relationship between a borrower and lender does not give rise to a duty of care under Massachusetts law.’ … There are some exceptions to this general rule. For example, mortgage holders do in fact have a duty to ‘act in good faith and must use reasonable diligence to protect the interests of the mortgagor’ in the context of an extrajudicial foreclosure and exercise of power of sale.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized and enforced in G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The case involves a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the SJC’s opinion, as excerpted, does not analyze or decide that § 14 issue. The Housing Court judge found for Gonzalez on that counterclaim, but then dismissed it to avoid cumulative damages, and the SJC’s discussion focuses on c. 93A emotional distress damages and warranty of habitability, not on whether Haddad’s conduct legally constituted a § 14 quiet‑enjoyment breach. Thus, this opinion is not authority for the proposition that similar conduct amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under § 14.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: "After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs.... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims."

*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 77.proposition: As a direct and foreseeable result, Plaintiff has suffered property damage, increased utility costs, and emotional distress associated with living in a persistently damp, unhealthy environment.
*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 77.support_reasoning: The case concerns the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy and how those damages are calculated (based on contract rent versus the tenant’s personal share). It does not discuss or recognize specific categories of consequential damages such as property damage, increased utility costs, or emotional distress from a persistently damp or unhealthy environment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the particular types of damages listed in the proposition.
*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 77.relevant_excerpt: “Damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability are measured by ‘the difference between the value of the dwelling as warranted (the rent agreed on may be evidence of this value) and the value of the dwelling as it exists in its defective condition.’ … This measure of damages is purely compensatory. It ‘gives a tenant … the benefit of the bargain because the implied warranty of habitability is part of the bargain’ the tenant makes with a landlord when the tenant agrees to pay rent.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff’s cooperation with city inspectors and the Defendant’s subsequent threats of lease nonrenewal further illustrate retaliatory motive, supporting a finding of willful interference.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not mention the plaintiff’s cooperation with city inspectors, retaliatory motive, threats of nonrenewal, or willful interference in response to such cooperation. Instead, it addresses failure to provide heat as a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and clarifies that landlord liability does not depend on intent or financial ability. Thus, it provides no authority for the specific retaliatory-motive proposition stated.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff’s cooperation with city inspectors and the Defendant’s subsequent threats of lease nonrenewal further illustrate retaliatory motive, supporting a finding of willful interference.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss retaliatory motive, threats of nonrenewal, or any theory of willful interference based on a tenant’s cooperation with city inspectors. The case focuses on security deposit violations, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability, utilities, and Chapter 93A applicability. Nothing in the reasoning or holdings addresses retaliation or lease nonrenewal threats, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
